Early religions engendered the concept of man being subservient to a higher being. This higher being's needs were placed above man's individual needs. The sense of community came about by trying to satiate the needs of their gods. The ancient Egyptians were as advanced as they were because they believed their pharaohs were gods and sacrificed greatly to please them. While it's traditional to believe that the pyramids were built by slaves, they weren't. They were built by skilled artisans.
 
 
 Eventually that happened and is what we see currently in religion, but it didn't start that way. Cave paintings don't depict images of Gods or the supernatural. Man sacrificed to gain something or for protection. His intent was not simply to honor the Gods for that reason alone. 
 
 People settled because of agriculture not to please the Gods. Man copied or it was instinctual to be a pack animal. Nomadic people formed tribes, tribes became farmers, farms became villages and then towns and cities. Religion was present and played a role, but is not what caused growth or kept the inhabitants from going back to being nomadic.

That isn't really supporting the idea that religion was the motivation behind their advances.
